article.description: David West watched most of the first half from the bench because of two quick fouls, then made up for lost time and finished with a season-high 24 points as Xavier (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) beat Ball State 87-58 on Friday night.
article.headline: West gives scouts a second-half show
article.linkText: West takes command in second half of Xavier's win
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- Those 12 NBA scouts eager to see David West could have showed up at halftime and not missed a thing. West watched most of the first half from the bench because of two quick fouls, then made up for lost time and finished with a season-high 24 points as Xavier (No. 20 ESPN/USA Today, No. 21 AP) beat Ball State 87-58 on Friday night. A well-rested West repeatedly drove to the basket for dunks and layups as the Musketeers (6-2) blew open the game with a 23-6 run at the start of the second half. West was held to four points in the first half. As soon as he got back on the floor, Ball State (5-4) was done. "He's not a guy you're going to stop,'' Ball State coach Tim Buckley said. The Cardinals couldn't even keep up. The 6-foot-9 power forward made 10 of his 11 shots from the field, all but one of them on moves to the basket. He also had nine rebounds and blocked a shot in only 20 minutes on the court. "I don't think I've sat that long since my freshman year,'' said West, who picked up his second foul at 15:28 of the first half. "I knew once I got the second one, I was done for the first half. "I just wanted to come out and play. I hadn't been on the floor. At halftime, I jumped some rope and got loose.'' West also took turns guarding long-range shooter Chris Williams, who scored most of his 24 points after the game was out of reach. A dozen NBA scouts showed up to see West make some moves and score some points. In the second half, he put on a show worthy of a potential first-round pick. He scored 12 consecutive points in the first 3:31 of the second half, topping off his one-man run with a steal, drive and one-hand dunk that broke open the game. West scored 20 points in the second half. "They were in some kind of matchup zone,'' said point guard Lionel Chalmers, who had nine of Xavier's 23 assists. "They were leaving the middle open, so that was the plan -- attack. If you get him going early, he can get everyone else involved.'' West was determined to make up for his ineffective 13-point performance during a 10-point loss to Mississippi State, but came out too aggressive, picking up those quick fouls. Xavier's troubles doubled when Anthony Myles, the Musketeers' other front-line scoring threat, got his second foul at 11:06 and joined West on the bench for the rest of the half. With its top two front-line scorers out, Xavier used its switching man-to-man defense to stay ahead. Williams picked up his third foul when he pushed off at 6:34 of the half, sending him to the bench. Cameron Echols hit three jumpers as Ball State cut a 10-point deficit to 31-27 at halftime. The rest was West. He banked a leaning jump shot off the backboard to start the 23-6 run that put Xavier up 54-33. West had 16 points in the spurt, including a pair of free throws after Buckley got a technical foul. Buckley said he was screaming at his team to play defense when he got the technical. During the next timeout, Buckley went on the floor to try to calm the frustrated Williams, who got bumped around by Xavier's tight defense. Buckley spent the rest of the timeout yelling at the referees. Ball State never got closer than 17 points the rest of the way. The game ended with a few hard feelings. Williams held the ball near midcourt as the final seconds ticked down, conceding the game, and Xavier's Dedrick Finn poked it away and took off down the court. Williams ran him down, and the two tumbled on the floor as the buzzer sounded. A few words were exchanged, but nothing more. "I don't think I've ever seen a guy try to steal it with .6 seconds left to get another basket,'' Buckley fumed. Xavier coach Thad Matta talked to his freshman guard afterward. "I told Dedrick that I'd just let the clock run out there,'' Matta said.
